audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker stating the intention to teach how to make a video with pictures and music, or a slideshow, on an iPhone. He mentions two options: one with just an iPhone and another with iMovie, speaking in an instructional tone. This is followed by music, a melancholic tune with a folk-pop feel, accompanied by what sounds like a video montage featuring images, possibly from Cape Town, as mentioned by the speaker during an interjection. The speaker states that the listener is about to learn everything about making a video using their iPhone. The speaker introduces himself as Dean Paman from Travelvids.tv and welcomes the viewer to an iPhone video editing tutorial series, with the music continuing in the background. This leads to the next step of making a slideshow video.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a way to view photos as a slideshow with music on an iPhone using the Photos app, explaining the steps for accessing the slideshow feature, and mentioning that images are randomly grouped with unique transitions. He continues, noting the ability to change the theme, music, repeat function, and speed. He then emphasizes how quickly a good-looking slideshow can be created. He also mentions the option to stream the slideshow to a television, but also sadly notes that the slideshow function does not allow for exporting the content as a video. The male speaker then ends with a tone of assurance, suggesting not to worry, because there's an easy workaround.

The clip begins with one male speaker instructing on how to screen record, emphasizing actions with a helpful tone, such as "when you slide up on your iPhone screen". The speaker continues guiding the listener through steps like customizing the control center, finding the screen recording option, and starting the recording. This speaking is accompanied by gentle background music. The speaker discusses setting up the screen and starting a slideshow. The music softens, and the speaker concludes by explaining how to stop recording and where the video is saved.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a video editing tutorial. He suggests exploring third-party video editing apps for more control. He indicates, "let's close this down" and transition to showing editing apps. He shares that he uses two apps: Splice, which he identifies as his "paid for or professional editor", and iMovie as his "quick job movie maker".

A male speaker starts by indicating an intention to use iMovie for creating slideshows with music, mentioning three reasons for this decision: that it is better suited to the task, free, and comes with the phone. He proceeds to give instructions, starting with opening iMovie and initiating a new project. He explains the choice between "movie" and "trailer", and opts for the former to have full control. He then tells the listener to select clips individually or as a group. The speaker observes that the video duration is long, considering the number of images, adding that it will take too long to show the first image. He announces his intention to add music before editing.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining how music will affect clip length, advising to import music. He offers several options like soundtracks, personal music, and sound effects. He recommends using copyright free YouTube music channels. A new track is added, then a short instrumental music snippet begins playing. The male speaker expresses enjoyment, continuing by suggesting to change the image duration. The music briefly plays again. The speaker guides to tap on the image, describing how to trim the clip length. He gives a duration goal and then mentions the video length being much better. He ends by mentioning the Ken Burns effect.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining the Ken Burns effect, which animates images for movement by transitioning between a clip's beginning and ending states. He adds that, if you turn this off, the images remain static and boring.  Next, he describes choosing a start position for the first clip, then goes on to describe how to use the effect on two other clips. All this is said over upbeat and rhythmic synth music. The speaker then notes that iMovie adds the Ken Burns effect automatically, but enhancement can make it more jumpy, depending on the music used.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing transitions in a video editing app. He mentions that the default setting places a crossfade, which he finds annoying but accepts as part of a free app. He says the user can choose between different transitions. The speaker demonstrates adding a slide effect and mentions that the direction of the slide can be changed. He suggests reviewing the video and adding more transitions randomly. He states that the transitions are looking a little lame and the main reason for this is because theyâ€™re too slow. Once a selection has been made at the bottom, speed can be increased. The male speaker describes adding 0.5 of a second to the transitions and the audio transitions to background music. The music is upbeat and pop-influenced. Finally, the male speaker interrupts the music, noting that a clip is still too long, even after adjustments have been made, and says the process of editing and shortening clips will continue to keep the video constantly moving and interesting.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing satisfaction with an editing process and stating that something "is starting to look right." He transitions to mentioning a "final version of the slideshow." Following this, music with a technological or electronic style begins, creating a positive or forward-looking mood. Once the music stops, the male speaker returns, encouraging the listener to hit "done" and name the project. He advises sharing the video, then a different male speaker, still positive in tone, hopes "this video was helpful." He promotes additional video tutorials and a video course that aims to transform the iPhone "from a simple calling device to a video creation tool." He concludes by directing the listener to a link and thanking them for watching.
